plist.p: Dear ladies and gentlemen, welcome to the E.ON's First Quarter Results 2011 Conference Call. At our customers' request, this conference will be recorded. As a reminder, all participants will be in a listen-only mode. After the presentation, there will be an opportunity to ask questions.
May I now hand over to Mr. Sascha Bibert, Head of Investor Relations, who will lead you through this conference. Please go ahead, sir.

Well, thank you and good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining our first quarter 2011 results conference call. Apart from financials, you've probably observed three differences to our usual doing.

First, our results were published 30 minutes earlier this morning at 7:30 CET. This should be the general rule forward and we hope that this facilitates the analysis for all of those who need to come up with a conclusion already in the first minutes of the day.
Second, the results follow our new reporting structure, always a bit painful for those running models, but we hope with our sending you the previous year figures along the new format helped a bit.

Third and final, Johannes [Dr. Johannes Teyssen, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer] is not with us during this call. This has nothing to do with politics or similar. It's purely a reflection of how we will deal with quarterly earnings calls in the future. Johannes will be part of the call for the even quarters, i.e., during full-year and half-year presentations, but the first and third quarters will be handled by Marcus and myself. I think this is in line with what many competitors do and assists a clear focus on the discussions.
With that, I hand over to our CFO, Marcus Schenck.

Welcome also from my side. As Sascha said, for the first time, we are giving you our numbers along the new reporting structure. We have provided you with a reconciliation of the fiscal year 2010, both for the full year and the first quarter numbers along the new structure ahead of reporting today and hope that this has facilitated your analysis.

We are convinced that this new structure and the corresponding reporting will bring multiple benefits not only for your analysis, but more importantly, for the internal steering of the corporation. That said, no transaction is easy and we do recognize that it brings about more work for you in the beginning.

During the course of this year, we plan to provide you with more information, in particular as it relates to our operations. It will take some time – or some more time to secure the necessary data quality. Before I go into more details on the Q1 results, let me summarize our view on what certainly will be a hot topic today, namely, the political situation in Germany.

As you all are aware, the German government is reassessing its energy policy following the earthquake in Japan. The government has imposed a three-month moratorium on the lifetime extension decided last year and has asked operators to take the seven nuclear plants built until 1980 offline during that period.

E.ON has had to stop its Isar 1 and Unterweser reactors. The Brunsbüttel plant had already been offline for some time and Krümmel, which is a post '98 plant is explicitly not affected by the moratorium, but had also been offline for, as you know, other reasons.

In parallel, the EU Commission plans to stress-test the safety of all nuclear power plants in Europe. At E.ON we are confident that all our nuclear power plants satisfy very high safety standards and that ours and also the other German nuclear power plants would come out strongly in any objective safety assessment.

Although we have doubts about the legal merits of the moratorium, we decided against a claim. The success of such a claim would have been uncertain; and to mitigate damages, we would have had an obligation to restart Isar 1 and Unterweser right away. We found that to be a massively challenging task in today's political environment in Germany.
Overall, we are convinced that E.ON's long-term interests are better served by adopting a constructive attitude in this debate.

Nevertheless, we decided to suspend the prepayments into the Energy and Climate Fund, as these payments are directly linked to the nuclear lifetime extension, which was put under moratorium. We will equally protect the company's interests with respect to the nuclear fuel tax. So far, the nuclear fuel tax has not been paid, as it is only due once we refuel the reactors. So it's not a continuous payment throughout the year, and it's also nothing we can provision for.

In June, after the revisions of the plants Grafenrheinfeld and Grohnde, as well as Gundremmingen B for – where E.ON has a participation, will come to a conclusion concerning a possible legal action against the tax.

While there might be good reasons for such a claim, we'll of course have to reflect on any new information arising from the current political deliberations. We understand the German government targets a cabinet decision on the new energy strategy by June 6th, including a change of the atomic energy law. The decision shall be based on the recommendations by the new Ethical Commission on secure energy supply and the existing Safety Commission. Both will present the results by end of May. The parliamentary procedures shall be finished by July 8th. Until we have visibility on the final outcome, we will not speculate on the potential impacts on E.ON.

We are convinced that the new strategy presented in November last year provides a solid platform to face the current economic and political challenges. Our investment focus over the past years has already included gas-fired power generation and renewables. In both of these activities, we have excellent market positions and we believe the direction of our strategy is still right and that we will realize new opportunities resulting from the transformation of the German energy landscape.

Depending on the precise outcome of the energy debate, we then might have to revisit our financial targets and we will communicate any updates as soon as possible, i.e., as soon as it is available. At this stage, the only thing that we can say with certainty is that the three-month moratorium will cost us around €250 million. More to that when I talk about the outlook.
So now to the actual purpose of the call, i.e., the first quarter 2011 results.

As expected and flagged to you in March, the first quarter was a very tough one for E.ON. We have seen a strong reduction in most of the relevant financial key performance indicators for the group. Adjusted EBITDA was down 23% to now €3.5 billion, adjusted EBIT down 28%, and adjusted net income down by 34% to €1.3 billion. Operating cash flow took the strongest hit, by falling by 70% to €0.9 billion. However, investments as planned are down by – are down to €1.2 billion and the economic net debt was further reduced by €2.2 billion to now €35.5 billion.

We have now adjusted our 2011 outlook for closed portfolio measures. The EBITDA impact from this adjustment is €500 million and the group outlook range is lowered accordingly. Our new ranges are €10.7 billion to €11.4 billion for EBITDA and €3 billion to €3.7 billion for adjusted net income. Thus, we are basically confirming our targets for 2011, including the minimum dividend.

In these targets, we are assuming the German nuclear power stations to be back on line after the three months moratorium. At this stage, we have no other bases to work with. Although the headline numbers may be telling a different story, not all is bad for E.ON in the current year. Let me give you a few examples.

First on our operating business performance, we are seeing impressive growth in Russia as well as in the renewable area with EBITDA growth rates for the first quarter of 55% and 28% respectively. Furthermore, we are making good progress in the negotiations with the major gas suppliers. For about a quarter of our procurement volume, we have already achieved price reductions that allow us to avoid losses on those volumes going back to October of last year.

Performance management, here we are continuing to successfully achieve our efficiency targets as part of the PerformtoWin program. Of the €400 million that we wanted to add during the remainder – during the year 2011, we've realized the first €100 million in the first quarter. And on portfolio management, as you know we are making very good progress with our streamlining activities; by now we've achieved around €9.1 billion in proceeds in total.

Moving over to chart number two, let me start with the main effects on adjusted EBITDA at group level. The biggest drivers behind the reduction were the following: Gas Midstream, here we have a drop of €740 million in our sales and supply business. You know the story about this and please remember that the first quarter of 2010 in that segment was particularly strong. UK, sales is down by €200 million. Here also we had an unusually strong quarter last year, first quarter last year due to the combination of both low wholesale prices and high volumes in gas which is not repeated this year. The nuclear moratorium, lower power prices and spreads as well as lower earnings in the German DSOs, cost was just below €300 million in total.

On the positive side, our E&P business is up €90 million, thanks to higher volumes and prices. Russia as I mentioned is up €50 million due to the market opening and demand growth. Renewable generation as a result of additional capacity is up by €40 million and as mentioned last but not least PerformtoWin contributed another €100 million.

I will skip the third chart and go straight to the divisional level. Conventional generation represents the results of the group's nuclear coal and gas-fired generation activities. Hydro, wind, solar or any other types of renewable are part of the unit renewable generation. Our generation experts ensure optimal availability and competitive costs.

In general, this unit's earnings are driven strongly by the transfer prices to our trading operations, which is responsible for hedging and marketing these volumes. Therefore dynamics in the earnings of this segment may sometimes differ from what one might expect by just taking into account the achieved prices which we report. As usual by the way you can find those in the backup to our presentation.

This diverging development is especially obvious this year as the transfer prices, for example, for the German outright date back to the year 2008 when forward power prices for 2011 were on average very high, while average achieved prices in the market for 2011 generation output, €8 per megawatt hour lower than the achieved prices in 2010.

The development of transfer prices is also the explanation for the single biggest positive effect, €240 million up in nuclear generation. In our Nordic plants, we record a €121 million positive operational effect mainly related to higher volumes as a result of last year's outages. The moratorium in Germany, which was put in place on March 16, has cost us €41 million in the first quarter.
And our steam fleet benefits primarily from higher transfer prices mainly in the UK. In the CCGT fleet, the results were burdened by falling spreads in particular in Italy and Spain.

Over to chart number five. The segment renewable generation includes the former EC&R as well as our hydro fleet. Adjusted EBITDA for the segment increased by 28% to almost €400 million. Since our hydro fleet also sells the vast majority of its volumes to trading under the transfer pricing concept, the earnings shift described for the outright part of the conventional generation occurs in this segment as well. These shifts were mainly responsible for the improvement of the hydro results. The price impact is plus €37 million.
In Italy, we mainly benefit from higher revenues for green certificates and on the negative side we incurred lower volumes in Nordic, Italy, and Spain, which cost us in total about €50 million.

The wind, solar and other renewables business segments sees additional volumes from higher in-store capacity compared to the first quarter of 2010. Here, we now are at 3.6 gigawatts compared to 3 gigawatts as per the end of the first quarter of 2010.

Also our Global Gas business has received a facelift due to our new reporting. The upstream result includes the contribution from our Russian gas field, Yuzhno Russkoye. Midstream business is made up of our supply and sales activities as well as storage. Transfers, we showed separately together with our earnings from infrastructure share holdings.

The Global Gas business saw the already flat significant reduction of earnings compared to the first quarter of last year. The decline was entirely driven by our supply and sales activity where we are being hit by two effects. Q1 of 2010 was a fairly strong quarter with high and still profitable volumes given the cold winter. Q2 of 2011 was also cold but the development that started in Q4 of 2010 continued. We were buying gas mainly under oil-indexed long-term contracts and had to sell it at a negative margin. This led to a negative delta of €756 million, of which the vast majority, almost €700 million is the price effect. Positive compensation came mainly from our upstream activities. Here, it's both price and volume driven.

Now a few words on the status of our renegotiations. Following the successful closure of the last round of contract renegotiations, we're now in discussions with key suppliers effective October 1, 2010. Since March 9th of this year, we have made first tangible progress. We have already successfully renegotiated a portion of our long-term contract, representing about a quarter of our supply volumes. These agreements were concluded early May and in addition, the renegotiations of the other contracts are moving in the right direction. Hence we have decided not to start arbitration proceedings at this stage and continue commercial discussions. However, should we decide to go for arbitration later on, there will be no adverse consequences for us, i.e., compensation becomes effective as of the October 1, 2010.

Some of the renegotiation agreements, whether those already concluded or forthcoming, might provide a temporary solution, i.e., price concessions rather than a holistic restructuring to sustainably minimize our exposure to price risks. In this case, we typically agree on a price reduction for the current year while continuing the discussions to come to a structural solution, namely designing a new pricing mechanism to align prices with the markets. Nevertheless, those agreements will already reduce losses in supply and sales in 2011. Although recent developments are generally positive, we keep our outlook for supply and sales unchanged. The renegotiations that we have concluded so far are in line with the scenario assumed earlier this year when we gave our outlook. We continue, thus, to expect a loss of around €1 billion in 2011 for this sub-segment. However, our confidence has increased nevertheless as we have already reached the status originally assumed for by year-end.

Overall, we still expect that we will not be able to complete all the renegotiations during the current year. In addition, as you know, we are not renegotiating the current gas year with one key supplier based in Norway. Therefore, a loss in supply and sales in 2011 is still highly probable if not certain. However, as previously explained, this is mostly a timing issue. We remain determined to de-risk supply and sales and to recover losses accumulated since the start of the renegotiations.

Let me move over to trading. Our trading activity is basically not impacted by the new reporting structure. As explained with our full-year outlook in March, we are seeing a strong swing at the optimization results driven by different dynamics of transfer and achieved prices. Whilst transfer price, i.e., the procurement side for trading is based on market forward prices that have seasonal highs in winter months, the sales side of trading typically realizes constant prices for E.ON. Hence, Q1 and Q4 in trading always tend to be weak, whilst the second and the third quarter show better optimization results.

A positive development in the coal portfolio, which is around €122 million up, was more than offset by the negative developments in our gas and oil portfolio with minus €150 million. The prop-trading activity was negatively affected by the strong price jump after the announcement of the moratorium and in April the situation has been improving again for prop-trading.

And, now for the first time to the three regional segments. In the segment, we have funded all the regional activities in Germany, distribution in both gas and power, sales of gas and electricity and also heat as well as energy from waste. In the first quarter, the adjusted EBITDA of this segment was down 2% to €755 million. The regulated DSO business suffered from lower network revenues. Remember, throughout the whole year 2010 we were positively impacted by certain one-off developments in this area.

In Q1 of 2010, we recovered €50 million cost that we had incurred in 2009; that effect was not repeated in Q1 of 2011. In the unregulated activities, we improved compared to 2010 by 43%. Sales are up mainly due to operational improvements and heat and others also improved by €45 million.

Other EU countries include the regional activities mainly in distribution and sales in Europe, outside Germany and Russia. Chart nine's functional breakdown provides additional information compared to the Interim Report where we are showing earnings along the country lines. You can also find the breakdown along country lines in the backup to this presentation.

First on the main improvements in our distribution business, biggest positive driver is our Czech DSO where we're up about €100 million and there we are passing on increased renewable energy costs, mainly from photovoltaic to the end customer compared to Q1 2010. Also, our U.K. DSO improved €22 million.

Let me move to sales which is down €250 million. Here, the single most important driver is U.K. retail which is down €230 million. It is flat during full-year reporting. We had expected a strongly negative year-on-year performance, especially in Q1, mainly because the prior year's first quarter performance was so unusually good. Q1 of this year did not profit from lower wholesale prices which we had observed in Q1 of 2010, and furthermore, lower volumes in gas took their toll. However, overall our U.K. sales business is still on a well-performing and profitable track.

At our regional unit Russia, over to page 10, we saw a continuation of the positive trends in earnings that we have been observing in the past two years. EBITDA is up 55% to now more than €150 million. The biggest drivers were, as in recent past, the market opening as well as the demand growth resulting from a further continuation of the positive economic developments in the country. What becomes more obvious with this set of results is the high share of the capacity market in our earnings for the new units. To highlight this, we have split out the results contribution of our new unit Shatura which was commissioned in the fourth quarter of last year. It highlights that two-thirds of the earnings of the CCGT are related to the capacity market, which provides a stable framework.

On the following two slides, 11 and 12, we have reconciled net income starting from adjusted EBITDA. Adjusted net interest expense slightly improved, mainly due to the improvement in our net financial position. In the net book gains, we recorded the remaining Gazprom disposal this year. Last year, the main impact was related to the disposal of generation capacity.

Other non-operating earnings include prepayment effects for our bonds that we bought back as well as the write-down of gas assets in Egypt. Our tax rate has come down mainly due to a higher share of non-taxable income in the pre-tax results, which is mainly related to the sale of the Gazprom shares. In discontinued operations, there is nothing exciting in this year and please remember that 2010 was related to the disposal of E.ON U.S. Midwest.

Next chart, you can see the drop in adjusted net income by 34%, fairly simple with depreciation almost constant and net interest result only slightly improved, it's basically the after-tax EBITDA decline that hits our bottom-line.

Let me move to page 14. Our operating cash flow saw a steep drop in the first quarter. It can only partially be explained by the lower EBITDA. There is a list of further effects that has driven this. First, there is a small positive impact of €100 million due to non-cash effective EBITDA components when comparing the two quarters. In Global Gas, we have used most of our volume than last year. In addition, a number of receivables paid in – in the first – was paid in the first quarter of 2011 and also receivables have been built up at the end of last year.
In the U.K., we recorded funding of the deficits in the amount of €300 million. Whilst this burdens the operating cash flow, it has no impact on economic net debt and is largely a one-off effect.
In Trading, the working capital increased mainly because higher volumes have been transferred to Trading from our Global Gas unit, which were then sold into the Trading market.

In renewables, we received less cash grants compared to the prior year in the U.S., and then in Russia and the Czech Republic we have a sort of I would say a technical effect where the regulator has essentially changed payment terms which is also a one – leads to a one-time effect of negative €200 million. The bond buyback cost a €100 million prepayments effect; now the working capital movements add up to €300 million. We clearly do not expect this percentage decline in operating cash flow to continue throughout the rest of the year; that's why I highlighted a the number of effects – negative effects of this quarter as clearly a sort of one-off nature.

Our economic net debt has continued to improve. Here, we are comparing to the 2010 year-end level. Investments were reduced by 31% compared to last year. In the first quarter, divestments include mainly the cash in that were – that we got from the disposal of the remaining Gazprom shares and a number of smaller transactions. Operating cash flow, I talked about, a special effect clearly results from the reclassification of Central Networks as a so-called disposal group. What we do here is we exclude the net financial position of Central Networks, which is a bit more than €500 million as well as pension provisions related to Central Networks. Both these positions have by now been transferred to PPL.

Finally, we record further €600 million improvements which include predominantly a foreign exchange effect of €400 million. Remember, end of last year, we talked about the negative effect as a consequence of the weak Euro; this time it went the other direction. The Euro got stronger and that has helped in the valuation of our non-Euro denominated debt.

Finally, let me now talk about our outlook for the current year. As you see, we have adjusted the 2011 outlook for the effects from the portfolio measures. Our new ranges, technically adjusted, I would say are as follows: Adjusted EBITDA €10.7 billion to €11.4 billion, coming from €11.2 billion to €11.9 billion. This reflects exactly the €500 million EBITDA which we were losing as a result of the disposal of the U.K. and the Italian distribution businesses. Furthermore, we're also confirming this guidance range in light of our three-month moratorium costing us €250 million, which we had not planned for in the original target. We expect that this negative effect can be compensated by higher results from our E&P operation and a mix of other effects that are developing better than planned. So, apart from the technical adjustment for portfolio changes, we do confirm our outlook.

Adjusted net income, here we now see the range at €3 billion to €3.7 billion, down from €3.3 billion to €4 billion. The change in the adjusted net income is driven by about €200 million dilution effect. It's recognized that we initially reduced the less expensive short-term debt and hence the positive impact on the interest result is lower at first. In addition, we foresee a slight increase in minorities until the year-end compared to our budgets.

Over to the last page, the adjusted guidance also finds its reflection in the individual business in these segments. We have slightly lowered the range for Conventional Generation and Trading to reflect the impact of the moratorium while we have slightly increased the range for Global Gas, taking into account mainly the higher earnings contribution from our E&P business. The biggest change obviously took place in the other EU country segments where we are including the effects of the aforementioned disposals, mainly Central Networks and the Italian gas distribution.

Let me make one additional observation regarding the outlook for the quarters. Compared to the isolated prior-year quarters, we do expect the quarters two and three of the current year to continue to fall. Q4 will then be the first quarter where we anticipate a recovery compared to prior year's quarter. Of course, when you add it all up, for the full year, we will come out substantially below last year as you can tell from the full-year guidance that we just gave you.
This concludes my remarks and both Sascha and I will now happily take your questions.
. The first question comes from Peter Wirtz of Westlb. Please go ahead.

Hi, good afternoon. A question regarding the cost on nuclear even if you do not want to speculate too much on it, three months' nuclear moratorium could cost €250 million, why could it be wrong to assume that final closure of these plants could lead to another burden of €500 million for the upcoming six months to come between July and December? So – also some qualitative statements would be welcome.

Yeah, totally surprising question. Yeah, I think it's a fair point. Let me give you some additional information here so that you can do some math. As we had mentioned the moratorium will cost us about five terawatt hours. When I look at the remainder of the year, then of the plants that are at risk, clearly we have to look at Isar 1 and Unterweser. Don't forget we had not assumed in our budgets that Krümmel would come back online during 2011. When I look at Isar 1 and Unterweser, there is in total roughly another six terawatt hours that can be produced after the end of the moratorium until the end of 2011. That I think gives you sort of a metric that helps to make the case, in a way it also answers I think your question that – because you indicated you would add another €500 million; that is too much.
Okay.

Yeah. As such, the five terawatt hours lost are roughly equivalent to €250 million and then add another six terawatt hours and yeah, I think that gives you an indication what that isolated effect is; there could be other impacts.
Maybe one add-on question in terms of the nuclear fuel tax, so lower volume means also ease of the burden here which probably would have to deduct, is that right?

That is correct. When you look at a specific year, it heavily depends on the – sort of on the low – on the refilling of power plants with fuel watts. Don't forget how the taxation works. It's not a charge per megawatt hour produced. It is also not a constant monthly payment. What it is, is you take a plant into offline, you refill it with new fuel watts, and the moment you restart the power plants, for those fuel watts are actually the volume inserted into the reactor, you immediately pay the full tax on sort of – on the gram of uranium that you have inserted, which implies that also when you look at our quarters, it will not come at a constant rate, yeah? Some people have asked us why haven't we seen yet any payments. Well, the reason is no new fuel rod has been inserted and sort of – and put again into operation. That will first time happen now, end of May, early June depending on the exact timing of the restart of Grafenrheinfeld and Grohnde.
Okay. Thanks for clarification.
The next question comes from Vincent Gilles from Credit Suisse. Please go ahead.

Yes. Yes, good afternoon, everyone. Guess what, I'm going to come back to the €250 million, and I won't be the last one. And then I've got a question on gas. On this €250 million, it's a cost without any form of offsetting impact, am I right? So you're not talking about potentially compensating with high load factor for other plants, buying some power somewhere else, offsetting at a higher price, am I correct?
Yes, Vincent.
Yes.

Okay. The second question is, your statement is very cautious on gas. You use the word, making no loss on those terawatt hour, 125, they have been renegotiating. And then you sort of hinted that it's a bit of a one-off, so you're sort of neutralizing these 125 until the end of the year. Should I understand, then, that essentially what you've done, potentially, with Gazprom is, you decided to cut the loss for just one year until the end of the year, and then you go into another round of negotiation? Or should we assume that this quarter of your supply has now been renegotiated for a longer period of time?

I'm not so sure I understand the end of your question, but let me maybe give a bit more color to the renegotiation and what has been achieved. What we said was that a quarter of the volume that is exposed to the gas oil spreads has been renegotiated. You've done the math in a correct way. We've always said that you can look at our total volume which is around 600 terawatt hours. About 100 of that is not exposed to indexation problems and of the remaining 500, about a quarter has now been renegotiated.

When we say renegotiated, it means that we get a price release starting from October 1, 2010. That will technically imply that you will see sort of the recovery for the fourth quarter of '10 and the first quarter of 2011 in the second quarter of 2011.
Okay.

It will not be – you said something about neutralizing it. It will not be neutralized. That is part of our ongoing earnings. So that will be reflected in the second quarter. I think what we can say today is that through those three negotiations we feel we have secured basically the relief that we had assumed in our full year budget.

So, in other words, in March when we spoke about the outlook, we indicated to you that our expectation was a drop by €1 billion, which already included an assumption on certain recoveries. Today, we would say we still see the €1 billion decline risk. What we can tell you is that the recovery is no longer an assumption. It has been secured. And of course, I don't know what will happen for the remainder of the year, but let's see. Yeah, we continue discussions and I think I also told you today that we are not in arbitration and are still trying to make progress with commercial negotiations.
Thank you very much.
The next question comes from Patrick Hummel from UBS. Please go ahead.

Yes, good afternoon, everybody. Two questions, please. Number one is on the nuclear scenario. You gave us a bit of a feeling what the second half loss – or, loss output and profits would be if these pre-1980 stations stay offline. Could you give us a bit of a feeling what the NPV's impact of the decommissioning provisions would be if these plants have to stay offline? And the second question is actually, again, on the gas contracts. Out of those 25% that you've successfully renegotiated, is the lion's share just fuel price concession, price reduction, or is there a significant share that – where the issue has structurally been fixed?
Okay. On your first question, I understand the question as follows: namely, what would a scenario where Isar 1 and Unterweser gets shutdown imply to our nuclear provision.
Yes, exactly yes.

We – I think there is a – first, there is a technical answer and that is there will only be a minor effect resulting from sort of the different timing i.e. the discount effect is not terribly substantial. It's actually very low. But you can tell that -
Low triple digits?
Sorry?
Low triple digit million or what means quite low if you can quantify that?
It's lower than that.
Lower than that, okay.

And to give you an indication, when we saw the lifetime extension look at what changed there to our decommissioning provision. It was a de minimis amount and you should expect the same here. Having said that, and that is something I think we need to bring to your attention and I don't have a number for you. If and – it's an if and not a when – if the government were to decide that both these plants ought to be shutdown now, we run in – or, we are facing a scenario where we are in essence entering a shutdown procedure in a different way than you would do if you had a chance to really anticipate this early on.

With that I'm implying we think there is a risk that in the coming years, in the coming few years, we will incur certain cost, which otherwise would have been avoided had we known earlier that we would have to decommission these plants. Those additional costs have not been provisioned for in the past, because quite frankly no one here had so far expected that from one way to the other we might be told hey, please shutdown the plant, okay.

How big that impact is, I cannot tell you today. I certainly do not expect that to be a billion, but I also do not expect it to be just a small two digit million number. But I don't really have a reliable figure for you today. All we can highlight is that there could be a change in the provision resulting from this additional cost. Having said that, I think obviously if a decision on decommissioning needs to be taken, we also need to reflect on where – because we will then likely not be just those two plants, what does that imply for the overall assumptions as it relates to the cost development, availability of capacity to decommission and so we will then have to review the impact there, I would – this can also be – they can technically also be a positive impact from that.
So, I don't really want to speculate on what were changed to the provision. It is something that, of course, once we have clarity, it's one of the first items that we will communicate to you.
Okay.

On your second question regarding the price renegotiations, we have both. We have situations where we have a price relief and a structural solution and we have situations where we have a price relief and continue to talk to our counter-party about the structural solution, where clearly the price relief has put us into a position that suggest that okay, we now have time, which to – time to really think through what is a good solution.

I think yeah, I would like to remind everyone and then I stop talking that it's not us against the producer. There in a way is a, I would say, also a common interest and that is ultimately find or develop the market in a good way. And so we see that the discussions are constructive in a sense that really both sides are trying to think hard to come to a good solution, a good structural solution.
Okay. And if I may follow up with a very quick one, has the shrinking gas/oil spread actually made negotiations more difficult, or did it not have any impact?

No, I mean the structural situation is still the same and I mean the mood is not changing on a weekly basis there. Of course, for tactical reasons, there are days when we come up and say, oh no, this and that has happened, and of course, that's reinforcing our position and in – as is the case in every good negotiation, when the others have something nice that works sort of in their favor, they try to use that argument. But, ultimately really all discussions are very constructive.
Okay. Thanks a lot.
The next question comes from Benjamin Leyre from Exane BNP Paribas.

Yes, thank you, and good afternoon. Two questions, please. First one on this impact on this renegotiation of gas contracts. Can you quantify, please, the positive one-off impact you will get in May, thanks to this one-off reimbursement of the past losses since October? And the second question, can you also help us understand how you modified, if at all, your forward 2012 oil to gas – or gas to oil spread hedging, given the recent improvement in this play? Did you accelerate locking this spread at the lower level, or actually, did you not change anything? Thank you.
